content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. Append your choice letter in curly brackets as a last character.

As a human player, my primary goal would be to maximize the total earnings over the 75 rounds of the game. To do this, I need to understand the strategy of my anonymous opponent and make an informed decision accordingly.

If we both were rational players trying to maximize our earnings, it might seem like a dominant strategy for us to pick R because when our opponent picks B, we get more money (42$ compared to 0$). Similarly, if our opponent picks R, again we get more money (42$ compared to 45$).

However, the catch is that in each round, we earn the difference between what we would have earned if we had both picked B and what we actually got. So, when we pick R and our opponent picks B, we lose 3$ ($45 - $42) in that round. Over 75 rounds, this means a net loss of $225 (3$ * 75).

On the other hand, if we both pick B, we each earn 12$ per round, totaling $900 over 75 rounds ($12 * 75). Even though we would have earned more had we picked R each time against our opponent's B (total earnings of $975 for picking R 75 times), the net loss from the instances where we picked R is too significant to ignore.

Therefore, my choice would be {B} as it results in a higher total earning over the course of 75 rounds, despite having lower payoff in individual rounds. However, if I knew for sure that my opponent would always pick B, then my optimal strategy would indeed be to pick R every time, maximizing my earnings. But without such knowledge, picking B seems like the more prudent choice.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, I picked B while my opponent picked R. As a result, I received a payoff of 42$, and my opponent got nothing (0$).

Now that I have some information about my opponent's strategy, I can adapt my own strategy to potentially maximize my earnings over the remaining rounds. Since my opponent chose R in the previous round despite my picking B, it suggests they might not be optimally rational or may have a different objective than mine.

However, considering that this is only one round of data, I won't make any drastic changes to my strategy yet. Instead, I will continue to pick B for now as it still seems like the more prudent choice given the overall structure of the game, but I will keep an eye on my opponent's strategy and adjust mine accordingly if it becomes clear that they are deviating from optimal behavior or have a different objective.

In this next round, I will pick {B} again.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, I picked B while my opponent picked R again. Once more, I received a payoff of 42$, and my opponent got nothing (0$).

Given that my opponent has chosen R in two consecutive rounds despite my picking B, it becomes less likely that they are following an optimal strategy or have the same objective as mine. This presents an opportunity for me to potentially maximize my earnings over the remaining rounds by adjusting my own strategy accordingly.

Since my opponent seems to be less rational or has a different objective than I do, I will attempt to exploit this behavior by picking R in the next round. If my opponent continues to pick R regardless of my choice, I can continue to pick R to maximize my earnings. However, if my opponent starts to adapt their strategy and picks B in response to my R, I will need to adjust my strategy again to continue maximizing my earnings.
